canonical_explanation.text: Work is done when a force causes displacement in its direction. Work = Force x Displacement x cos(angle). The SI unit is Joule (J). Kinetic energy is energy due to motion (KE = 1/2 mv^2). Potential energy is energy due to position (PE = mgh for gravitational). The work-energy theorem states that work done equals change in kinetic energy. The law of conservation of energy states energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed. Power is the rate of doing work (P = W/t = Fv), measured in Watts. Efficiency is the ratio of useful output to total input.
rules: Work = Force x Displacement x cos(theta)
SI unit of work is Joule (J) = Newton-meter
Positive work when force and displacement in same direction
Negative work when force and displacement in opposite directions
Zero work when force perpendicular to displacement or no displacement
Work-energy theorem: Work done = Change in KE
Conservation of energy: Total energy remains constant in isolated system
SI unit of power is Watt (W)

questions.question_text: Work is said to be done when:
questions.explanation_correct: Work is said to be done when a force causes an object to be displaced in the direction of the force. This is because work is defined as the product of the force applied and the displacement of the object in the direction of the force.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Work is not just done when a force is applied or when an object is displaced. For work to be done, the force must cause the object to move in the direction of the force. Simply applying a force or having an object move is not enough - the force and displacement must be in the same direction for work to be done.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of work is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of work is Joule (J) because work is defined as force multiplied by displacement in the direction of the force, and the SI unit of force is Newton and the SI unit of displacement is meter. Therefore, the SI unit of work is the product of these two, which is Newton-meter or Joule.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct SI unit of work. Newton is the SI unit of force, Watt is the SI unit of power, and Pascal is the SI unit of pressure. Work is a measure of the energy transferred by a force, and its SI unit is the Joule, which is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: The kinetic energy of a body depends on its:
questions.explanation_correct: The kinetic energy of a body depends on both its mass and velocity. The formula for kinetic energy is KE = 1/2 mv^2, where m is the mass and v is the velocity of the object. Increasing either the mass or the velocity of the object will increase its kinetic energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The kinetic energy of a body does not depend on its height. Kinetic energy is the energy of motion, and it is related to the mass and velocity of the object, not its position or height. The correct formula for kinetic energy is KE = 1/2 mv^2, where m is the mass and v is the velocity of the object.

questions.question_text: The formula for kinetic energy is:
questions.explanation_correct: The formula for kinetic energy is KE = (1/2)mv^2 because kinetic energy is the energy an object has due to its motion, and this formula takes into account the object's mass and velocity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct formula for kinetic energy is KE = (1/2)mv^2, not KE = mv or KE = mv^2. This is because kinetic energy is proportional to the square of the velocity, not just the velocity. The formula KE = mgh is for potential energy, not kinetic energy.

questions.question_text: Gravitational potential energy depends on:
questions.explanation_correct: Gravitational potential energy depends on the mass of the object and the height it is at, because the amount of potential energy an object has is directly proportional to its mass and the height it is raised to. This is why the correct answer is B) Mass and height.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gravitational potential energy does not depend on the velocity of the object, as that would determine the kinetic energy, not the potential energy. The correct answer is B) Mass and height, because the potential energy of an object in a gravitational field is calculated as PE = mgh, where m is the mass and h is the height.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of power is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C. Watt. Power is the rate of doing work, and the SI unit of power is the Watt (W), which is defined as 1 Joule per second (J/s).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect. Joule (J) is the SI unit of work or energy, not power. Newton (N) is the SI unit of force, not power. Hertz (Hz) is the SI unit of frequency, which is not related to power.

questions.question_text: Power is defined as:
questions.explanation_correct: Power is the rate of doing work, or the amount of work done per unit time. The formula for power is P = W/t, where P is power, W is work, and t is time. This matches option C, 'Work / Time', which correctly defines power.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options do not correctly define power. Option A, 'Force x Displacement', gives the formula for work, not power. Option B, 'Work x Time', is not the definition of power. Option D, 'Force / Time', gives the formula for acceleration, not power.

questions.question_text: According to the law of conservation of energy:

options.text: Energy can only be transformed from one form to another
Energy can be created but not destroyed

questions.explanation_correct: The law of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, but can only be transformed from one form to another. Therefore, option C is the correct answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The law of conservation of energy does not allow for the creation or destruction of energy. Energy can only be transformed from one form to another, such as from electrical energy to thermal energy. Options A and D are incorrect because they suggest that energy can be created, which goes against the law of conservation of energy.

questions.question_text: A force of 20 N moves an object 5 m in the direction of the force. The work done is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) 100 J. This is because work (W) is calculated as force (F) multiplied by displacement (d) in the direction of the force, i.e. W = F x d. In this case, the force is 20 N and the displacement is 5 m, so the work done is 20 N x 5 m = 100 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The work done is not A) 4 J, B) 25 J, or D) 500 J. These options do not correctly apply the formula for calculating work, which is W = F x d. The correct formula and values must be used to get the right answer of 100 J.

questions.question_text: When a porter carries a load on his head and walks horizontally, the work done against gravity is:
questions.explanation_correct: When the porter carries the load horizontally, the displacement of the load is in the horizontal direction. Since the force of gravity acts in the vertical direction, the angle between the force and the displacement is 90 degrees. As a result, the work done against gravity is zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The work done against gravity is zero because the displacement of the load is in the horizontal direction, while the force of gravity acts in the vertical direction. This means the angle between the force and the displacement is 90 degrees, and the cosine of 90 degrees is zero. Therefore, the work done against gravity is zero.

questions.question_text: If the velocity of a body is doubled, its kinetic energy becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: When the velocity of a body is doubled, its kinetic energy becomes four times greater. This is because the kinetic energy formula is KE = 1/2 mv^2, and when the velocity is doubled, the v^2 term becomes four times larger, making the overall kinetic energy four times greater.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the velocity of a body is doubled, its kinetic energy does not become double or half. The kinetic energy formula is KE = 1/2 mv^2, so when the velocity is doubled, the v^2 term becomes four times larger, making the overall kinetic energy four times greater. Therefore, the correct answer is that the kinetic energy becomes four times larger when the velocity is doubled.

questions.question_text: A body of mass 2 kg moving with velocity 4 m/s has kinetic energy:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 16 J. This is because the kinetic energy of a body is given by the formula KE = 1/2 mv^2, where m is the mass and v is the velocity. Plugging in the values, we get KE = 1/2 x 2 kg x (4 m/s)^2 = 16 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are: A) 8 J, C) 32 J, and D) 4 J. The correct formula for kinetic energy is KE = 1/2 mv^2, where m is the mass and v is the velocity. Plugging in the given values of m = 2 kg and v = 4 m/s, we get KE = 1/2 x 2 kg x (4 m/s)^2 = 16 J.

questions.question_text: A ball of mass 0.5 kg is raised to a height of 10 m. Its potential energy is (g = 10 m/s^2):
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 50 J. This is because potential energy is calculated as mass x acceleration due to gravity x height (PE = mgh). The mass of the ball is 0.5 kg, the acceleration due to gravity is 10 m/s^2, and the height is 10 m. Plugging these values in, we get PE = 0.5 x 10 x 10 = 50 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not accurately calculate the potential energy of the ball. Option A) 5 J is too low, option C) 100 J is too high, and option D) 500 J is way off. The correct formula to use is PE = mgh, which gives the right answer of 50 J when plugging in the provided values.

questions.question_text: A ball is dropped from a height. At the midpoint of its fall:
questions.explanation_correct: At the midpoint of the ball's fall, the kinetic energy (KE) and potential energy (PE) are equal. This is because as the ball falls, its PE is decreasing while its KE is increasing, and at the midpoint, they are equal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is incorrect because at the midpoint, the ball has both kinetic energy and potential energy - its KE is not maximum and its PE is not zero. Option D is incorrect because at the midpoint, the KE and PE are equal, not KE greater than PE.

questions.question_text: A machine does 600 J of work in 20 seconds. Its power is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 30 W. Power is the rate of doing work, which is calculated as the work done divided by the time taken. In this case, the machine did 600 J of work in 20 seconds, so its power is 600 J / 20 s = 30 W.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not represent the correct calculation of power. Option A) 12000 W is too high, as it would require the machine to do 12000 J of work in 1 second, which is not the case. Option C) 300 W is also incorrect, as it would require the machine to do 300 J of work in 1 second. Option D) 0.03 W is too low, as it would require the machine to do only 0.03 J of work in 1 second, which is not the case.

questions.question_text: According to the work-energy theorem, the work done on a body equals:

options.text: The change in its kinetic energy

questions.explanation_correct: The work-energy theorem states that the work done on a body equals the change in its kinetic energy. This means that the work done adds to or subtracts from the body's kinetic energy, causing it to change.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The work-energy theorem does not state that the work done equals the body's total energy or its potential energy. The work done equals the change in the body's kinetic energy, not its total or potential energy.

questions.question_text: A force of 50 N acts on a body at an angle of 60 degrees to the displacement. If the displacement is 10 m, the work done is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 250 J. This is because the formula for work done is Work = Force x Displacement x cos(angle), and plugging in the given values (50 N, 10 m, 60 degrees) gives 250 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are A) 500 J, C) 433 J, and D) 125 J. These answers do not correctly apply the formula for work done, which takes into account the angle between the force and displacement. The correct formula and calculations show that the work done is 250 J.

questions.question_text: A pump lifts 200 kg of water through a height of 15 m in 10 seconds. The power of the pump is (g = 10 m/s^2):
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 3000 W. This is calculated using the power formula P = W/t, where W is the work done (force x displacement) and t is the time taken. The work done is 200 kg x 15 m x 10 m/s^2 = 30,000 J, and the time taken is 10 seconds. Therefore, the power is 30,000 J / 10 s = 3,000 W.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not correctly apply the power formula. Option B) 300 W is too low, option C) 30,000 W is too high, and option D) 30 W is too low. The key is to correctly calculate the work done and divide it by the time taken to get the power.

questions.question_text: Two bodies of masses m and 4m have equal kinetic energies. The ratio of their velocities is:
questions.explanation_correct: The ratio of their velocities is 2:1 because kinetic energy is proportional to the square of the velocity (KE = 1/2 mv^2). Since the two bodies have equal kinetic energies, the ratio of their velocities must be the inverse ratio of their masses, which is 2:1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not correctly reflect the relationship between the kinetic energies and velocities of the two bodies. If the masses are in the ratio 1:4, then for the same kinetic energy, the velocities must be in the inverse ratio of the square roots of the masses, which is 2:1.

questions.question_text: A ball of mass 1 kg is dropped from 20 m height. What is its velocity just before hitting the ground? (g = 10 m/s^2)
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 20 m/s. This is because when a ball is dropped from a height, it gains kinetic energy due to its increasing velocity, which is equal to the loss in its potential energy. Using the formula for potential energy (PE = mgh), the potential energy lost is 1 kg x 10 m/s^2 x 20 m = 200 J. By the work-energy theorem, this equals the gain in kinetic energy, which is 1/2 mv^2. Solving for the velocity, we get v = 20 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect. Option A) 10 m/s is too low, as the velocity gained by the ball would be less than the potential energy lost. Option C) 14.14 m/s is also incorrect, as it does not match the calculated value of 20 m/s. Option D) 200 m/s is much too high and physically impossible for a ball dropped from 20 m height under normal gravity.

questions.question_text: A machine has an efficiency of 80%. If the input work is 500 J, the useful output work is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 400 J. This is because if the machine has an efficiency of 80%, it means that 80% of the input work is converted to useful output work. Therefore, if the input work is 500 J, the useful output work is 80% of 500 J, which is 400 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) 400 J. The other options are incorrect because they do not correctly calculate the useful output work. Option B) 625 J is too high, as the efficiency is only 80%. Option C) 100 J is too low, as it does not account for the 80% efficiency. Option D) 420 J is also incorrect, as it does not match the correct calculation of 80% of 500 J.

questions.question_text: The formula for gravitational potential energy is:
questions.explanation_correct: The formula for gravitational potential energy is PE = mgh, where m is the mass, g is the acceleration due to gravity, and h is the height. This formula captures the energy stored due to the object's position in a gravitational field.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A, PE = mv^2, is incorrect because this formula represents kinetic energy, not potential energy. Option C, PE = (1/2)mv^2, is also incorrect as it is the formula for kinetic energy. Option D, PE = Fxs, is the formula for work, not potential energy.

questions.question_text: Negative work is done when:

options.text: Force and displacement are in same direction
Force and displacement are in opposite directions

questions.explanation_correct: Negative work is done when the force and displacement are in opposite directions. This means that the force is acting against the direction of motion, and the work done is negative.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Negative work is not done when the force and displacement are in the same direction or perpendicular to each other. Negative work is only done when the force and displacement are in opposite directions, as this means the force is acting against the motion and the work done is negative.

questions.question_text: 1 horsepower (hp) is equal to:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 746 W. This is because 1 horsepower is equal to 746 watts, which is the standard conversion between the two units of power.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect. Option A) 736 W is close but not the exact conversion. Option C) 1000 W is too high, as 1 horsepower is less than 1000 watts. Option D) 100 W is far too low, as 1 horsepower is much greater than 100 watts.

questions.question_text: A car accelerates from rest to 20 m/s. If its mass is 1000 kg, the work done by the engine is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 200,000 J. The work done by the engine is equal to the change in kinetic energy of the car, which is calculated as (1/2)mv^2, where m is the mass of the car and v is its final velocity. With a mass of 1000 kg and a final velocity of 20 m/s, the work done is 200,000 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct because they do not accurately calculate the work done by the engine. The work done is equal to the change in kinetic energy of the car, which is (1/2)mv^2. With a mass of 1000 kg and a final velocity of 20 m/s, the work done is 200,000 J, not 400,000 J, 20,000 J, or 10,000 J.

questions.question_text: An object is lifted to height h. If it is then lifted to height 2h, its potential energy:
questions.explanation_correct: The potential energy of an object is directly proportional to its height (PE = mgh). If the height is doubled from h to 2h, the potential energy will also double, as it is directly proportional to the height.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not correctly explain how potential energy changes with height. Option B is incorrect because potential energy increases linearly with height, not exponentially. Option C is incorrect because the potential energy does in fact change when the height is changed. Option D is incorrect because the potential energy increases, not decreases, when the height is doubled.

questions.question_text: Power can also be expressed as:
questions.explanation_correct: Power can be expressed as force multiplied by velocity, because power is defined as the rate of doing work, and work is equal to force multiplied by displacement. Velocity is the rate of displacement, so power can be written as force times velocity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Power cannot be expressed as force divided by displacement, because power is the rate of doing work, which is a product of force and displacement, not their ratio. It also cannot be expressed as force times time, because power is the rate of work done, not just the total work done over time. While energy multiplied by time can give power, this is not a direct expression of power itself.

questions.question_text: At the lowest point of a swinging pendulum:

options.text: KE is maximum, PE is minimum
KE is minimum, PE is maximum
Both KE and PE are maximum
Both KE and PE are zero

questions.explanation_correct: At the lowest point of a swinging pendulum, the kinetic energy (KE) is maximum because the pendulum is moving the fastest, while the potential energy (PE) is minimum since the pendulum is at its lowest point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because: B) At the lowest point, the KE is maximum, not minimum, as the pendulum is moving fastest here. C) Both KE and PE cannot be maximum at the same point, as they are inversely related. D) Both KE and PE are not zero at the lowest point, as the pendulum has significant motion and is at its lowest position.

questions.question_text: A bullet of mass 20 g moving at 400 m/s has kinetic energy:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 1600 J. The kinetic energy of an object is given by the formula KE = 1/2 mv^2, where m is the mass and v is the velocity. Plugging in the values, we get KE = 1/2 x 0.02 kg x (400 m/s)^2 = 1600 J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not match the formula for kinetic energy. Option B) 3200 J is double the correct answer, which is incorrect. Options C) 8 J and D) 16 J are much smaller than the correct value, as they do not account for the high velocity of the bullet.

questions.question_text: One Joule is equal to:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 1 Newton x 1 meter. The SI unit of work is Joule (J), which is defined as the amount of work done when a force of 1 Newton is applied over a distance of 1 meter in the direction of the force.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not correctly represent the definition of Joule. Option A) 1 Newton x 1 second represents the unit of force (Newton) multiplied by time (second), which is the unit of momentum, not work. Option C) 1 Newton / 1 meter represents the unit of force per unit distance, which is the unit of pressure, not work. Option D) 1 Watt x 1 meter represents the unit of power (Watts) multiplied by distance, which is not the definition of Joule.

questions.question_text: Work done is zero when force is perpendicular to displacement.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, the statement is true. When the force is perpendicular to the displacement, the cosine of the angle between them is zero. This means that the work done, which is calculated as Force x Displacement x cos(angle), will be zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect. When the force is perpendicular to the displacement, the angle between them is 90 degrees. The cosine of 90 degrees is zero, so the work done would be zero. This is because work is only done when the force and displacement are in the same direction.

questions.question_text: Kinetic energy is always positive.
questions.explanation_correct: Kinetic energy is always positive because it is the energy of motion. The formula for kinetic energy is KE = 1/2 mv^2, where m is the mass of the object and v is its velocity. Since mass is always positive and the velocity squared is also positive, the kinetic energy of an object will always be a positive value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kinetic energy cannot be negative because it is a measure of the energy of motion. Some students may think kinetic energy can be negative, but this is not correct. Kinetic energy is always a positive value, as it is determined by the mass of the object and the square of its velocity. Kinetic energy represents the ability of a moving object to do work, which can never be a negative quantity.

questions.question_text: Potential energy can be negative depending on the choice of reference point.
questions.explanation_correct: Potential energy can be negative depending on the choice of reference point. For example, for an object near the Earth's surface, the potential energy is defined as mgh, where h is the height of the object above the Earth's surface. If the reference point is chosen at the Earth's surface, the potential energy is positive. However, if the reference point is chosen at infinity, the potential energy is negative.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Potential energy cannot be negative. Potential energy is always a positive quantity as it represents the energy stored in an object due to its position. It is calculated as mgh, where m is the mass, g is the acceleration due to gravity, and h is the height of the object. Since height is always a positive quantity, potential energy must also be positive. The choice of reference point does not affect the sign of potential energy.

questions.question_text: In an isolated system, the total mechanical energy always remains constant.
questions.explanation_correct: In an isolated system, the total mechanical energy (sum of kinetic energy and potential energy) remains constant. This is known as the law of conservation of energy, which states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. In an isolated system, there are no external forces acting on the system, so the total mechanical energy of the system remains constant. This is because energy cannot be created or destroyed, it can only be transformed from one form to another, such as between kinetic energy and potential energy.

questions.question_text: A machine with 100% efficiency does more work than the input work.
questions.explanation_correct: A machine with 100% efficiency cannot do more work than the input work. This is because the law of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed. If a machine had an efficiency of 100%, it would be able to convert all the input work into useful output work, but it cannot generate more work than the input.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. A machine with 100% efficiency cannot do more work than the input work. This is because 100% efficiency means that all the input work is converted into useful output work, with no loss. If a machine could do more work than the input, it would be violating the law of conservation of energy, which states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed.

questions.question_text: The work-energy theorem is valid only for constant forces.
questions.explanation_correct: The work-energy theorem is valid for both constant and variable forces. It states that the work done on an object equals the change in its kinetic energy, regardless of the nature of the force. This theorem is a fundamental principle in physics and applies to a wide range of situations, not just those involving constant forces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement that the work-energy theorem is valid only for constant forces is incorrect. The work-energy theorem is a general principle that applies to both constant and variable forces. It relates the work done on an object to the change in its kinetic energy, and this relationship holds true regardless of whether the force acting on the object is constant or varies during the motion.

questions.question_text: Friction always does negative work on a moving body.
questions.explanation_correct: Friction always does negative work on a moving body. This is because the force of friction acts in the opposite direction to the direction of motion, so the angle between the force and the displacement is greater than 90 degrees. As a result, the cosine of this angle is negative, and the work done by friction is negative.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'Friction always does negative work on a moving body' is true. Friction is a force that opposes the motion of a body, so it always acts in the opposite direction to the direction of motion. This means that the angle between the force of friction and the displacement is always greater than 90 degrees, and the cosine of this angle is negative. As a result, the work done by friction is always negative, which means that it reduces the total energy of the moving body.

questions.question_text: If the mass of a body is doubled while keeping velocity constant, its kinetic energy is doubled.
questions.explanation_correct: If the mass of a body is doubled while keeping the velocity constant, its kinetic energy will be doubled. This is because kinetic energy is proportional to the mass of the body (KE = 1/2 mv^2), so doubling the mass will double the kinetic energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the mass of a body is doubled while keeping the velocity constant, its kinetic energy will not be doubled. This is because kinetic energy is proportional to both the mass and the square of the velocity of the body (KE = 1/2 mv^2). Doubling the mass alone will only increase the kinetic energy by a factor of 2, not double it.

questions.question_text: A more powerful engine always does more work than a less powerful engine.
questions.explanation_correct: A more powerful engine does not always do more work than a less powerful engine. Power is the rate of doing work, measured in watts. Work is the total energy transferred, measured in joules. A more powerful engine can complete a task faster, but the total work done may be the same as a less powerful engine that takes longer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'A more powerful engine always does more work than a less powerful engine' is false. Power is the rate of doing work, not the total work done. A more powerful engine can complete a task faster, but the total work done may be the same as a less powerful engine that takes longer. The total work done depends on the force and displacement, not just the engine power.

questions.question_text: A stretched spring has elastic potential energy.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, a stretched spring has elastic potential energy. When a spring is stretched or compressed, it stores energy due to its elastic deformation. This stored energy is called elastic potential energy, and it is equal to the work done in stretching or compressing the spring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: No, the statement is not correct. A stretched spring has elastic potential energy, not kinetic energy. Kinetic energy is the energy of motion, while potential energy is the energy of position or configuration. In the case of a stretched spring, the stored energy is in the form of elastic potential energy, not kinetic energy.

questions.question_text: Work = Force x Displacement x cos(___).
questions.explanation_correct: The angle between the force and the direction of displacement is represented by the symbol theta (). This angle is used to calculate the work done, as the formula for work is Force x Displacement x cos(theta). The cosine function accounts for the component of the force that is in the same direction as the displacement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The formula for work is Force x Displacement x cos(theta), where theta is the angle between the force and the direction of displacement. The accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is 'theta', as this is the specific variable that represents the angle in the work formula. Inserting any other variable or term would not correctly complete the formula and would therefore be incorrect.

questions.question_text: Kinetic energy is the energy due to ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Kinetic energy is the energy an object has due to its motion. When an object is moving, it has kinetic energy because of its moving state. This is the correct answer, as kinetic energy is the energy of motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'motion'. Kinetic energy is not the energy due to position or location, but rather the energy an object has because it is in motion. Kinetic energy is calculated as 1/2 times the mass of the object times the square of its velocity, which shows it is the energy of motion.

questions.question_text: Power is defined as the rate of doing ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Power is defined as the rate of doing work, because work is the amount of energy transferred when a force is applied over a distance. The faster this energy is transferred, the greater the power required. So the correct answer is 'work'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be 'energy'. While power is related to energy, it is not defined as the rate of doing energy. Power is specifically the rate of doing work, which is the product of force and displacement in the direction of the force. The SI unit for power is Watts, which is Joules per second, showing it is a measure of the rate of work being done.

questions.question_text: Gravitational potential energy equals mass times g times ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Gravitational potential energy is the energy an object has due to its position in a gravitational field. The formula for gravitational potential energy is PE = mgh, where m is the mass of the object, g is the acceleration due to gravity, and h is the height or vertical position of the object. Therefore, the missing term in the question is 'height'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be 'mass'. While mass is a factor in gravitational potential energy, the formula is PE = mgh, where h represents the height or vertical position of the object, not the mass. The mass is a separate variable in the equation.

questions.question_text: According to the law of conservation of energy, energy can neither be created nor ___.
questions.explanation_correct: According to the law of conservation of energy, energy cannot be created or destroyed, it can only be transformed from one form to another. This means that the total amount of energy in a closed system remains constant and is neither increased nor decreased.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'destroyed'. The law of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, it can only be transformed. This means that the total amount of energy in a closed system remains constant and cannot be increased or decreased. The option 'destroyed' is the accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question.

questions.question_text: The work-energy theorem states that work done equals the change in ___ energy.
questions.explanation_correct: The work-energy theorem states that the work done by a force is equal to the change in the kinetic energy of the object. This is because the work done on an object increases its kinetic energy, which is the energy of motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be potential energy. The work-energy theorem states that the work done equals the change in kinetic energy, not potential energy. Potential energy is the energy an object has due to its position or configuration, while kinetic energy is the energy an object has due to its motion.

questions.question_text: Efficiency of a machine = (Useful output / Total input) x ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The efficiency of a machine is the ratio of the useful output to the total input, multiplied by 100%. This is because efficiency is a measure of how effectively the machine converts the input energy into useful work, and it is typically expressed as a percentage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The efficiency of a machine is not just the ratio of useful output to total input, but rather the ratio multiplied by 100%. This is because efficiency is a measure of how effectively the machine is converting the input energy into useful work, and it is typically expressed as a percentage. The correct answer, therefore, is 100%.

questions.question_text: If velocity is doubled, kinetic energy becomes ___ times.
questions.explanation_correct: The kinetic energy of an object is proportional to the square of its velocity (KE = 1/2 mv^2). So if the velocity is doubled, the kinetic energy becomes four times the original value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'four'. This is incorrect because kinetic energy is proportional to the square of velocity. If the velocity is doubled, the kinetic energy becomes four times the original value, not two times. This is because the KE formula has a v^2 term, and when v is doubled, v^2 becomes 4 times the original value.

questions.question_text: When force and displacement are in opposite directions, the work done is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: When the force and displacement are in opposite directions, the work done is negative. This is because the work formula is Work = Force x Displacement x cos(angle), and the angle between the force and displacement is 180 degrees, making cos(180) = -1, resulting in negative work.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'negative'. The work done is negative when the force and displacement are in opposite directions. This is because the work formula is Work = Force x Displacement x cos(angle), and the angle between the force and displacement is 180 degrees, making cos(180) = -1, resulting in negative work. The work done cannot be positive in this case, as the force and displacement are in opposite directions.

questions.question_text: 1 kilowatt equals ___ watts.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is 1000 watts because 1 kilowatt (kW) is equal to 1000 watts (W). This is because the prefix 'kilo' (k) represents 1000 units of the base unit, which in this case is the watt (W).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be something other than 1000 watts, such as 100 watts. This is wrong because 1 kilowatt (kW) is equal to 1000 watts (W), not 100 watts. The prefix 'kilo' (k) means 1000, so 1 kilowatt is equal to 1000 watts.

questions.question_text: Total mechanical energy = Kinetic energy + ___ energy.
questions.explanation_correct: The total mechanical energy of an object is the sum of its kinetic energy and potential energy. This is because an object can have energy due to its motion (kinetic energy) as well as energy due to its position or height (potential energy). The total mechanical energy is the combination of these two forms of energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'Potential'. The total mechanical energy of an object is not just its kinetic energy alone. It also includes the potential energy of the object, which is the energy it possesses due to its position or height. The total mechanical energy is the sum of the kinetic energy and the potential energy of the object.

questions.question_text: Power can also be expressed as Force multiplied by ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Power can be expressed as Force multiplied by velocity because power is the rate of doing work, and work is defined as the product of force and displacement. Since velocity is the rate of displacement, power can be written as the product of force and velocity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'velocity'. The incorrect answer would be something like 'time' or 'acceleration'. However, power is defined as the rate of doing work, which is the product of force and velocity. Therefore, the correct expression for power is force multiplied by velocity.

questions.question_text: Arrange the energy transformations as a ball is thrown upward and falls back:
ordering_items: Maximum KE at the moment of throw
Maximum PE at the highest point
KE and PE equal at midpoint going up
Maximum KE just before hitting ground
correct_answer: Maximum KE at the moment of throw
KE and PE equal at midpoint going up
Maximum PE at the highest point
Maximum KE just before hitting ground
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of energy transformations is: At the moment of throw, the ball has maximum kinetic energy. As it rises, its kinetic energy decreases and potential energy increases, until at the highest point the kinetic and potential energies are equal. On the way down, the potential energy decreases and the kinetic energy increases, reaching a maximum just before hitting the ground.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: At the highest point, the ball has maximum potential energy, not maximum kinetic energy. The maximum kinetic energy occurs at the moment of throw, not just before hitting the ground. The correct order is: Maximum KE at the moment of throw, KE and PE equal at midpoint going up, Maximum PE at the highest point, Maximum KE just before hitting ground.

questions.question_text: Arrange these power values from smallest to largest:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order from smallest to largest power values is: 100 watts, 746 watts, 1 kilowatt (1000 watts), and 1 megawatt (1,000,000 watts). This is because as the units become larger, the power values increase exponentially.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: 746 watts, 100 watts, 1 kilowatt, 1 megawatt. This is wrong because 746 watts is smaller than 1 kilowatt (1000 watts), and 100 watts is the smallest value in the list. The correct order arranges the power values from smallest to largest, taking into account the unit conversions between watts, kilowatts, and megawatts.

questions.question_text: Arrange these objects in order of increasing kinetic energy (mass 1 kg each):
questions.explanation_correct: The objects are arranged in order of increasing kinetic energy because kinetic energy is directly proportional to the square of the velocity. An object at rest has zero kinetic energy, an object moving at 2 m/s has less kinetic energy than one moving at 3 m/s, and an object moving at 4 m/s has the highest kinetic energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to arrange the objects from lowest to highest velocity, which does not correctly represent the order of increasing kinetic energy. Kinetic energy depends on the square of the velocity, so an object moving at 4 m/s has more kinetic energy than one moving at 3 m/s, even though 4 m/s is a higher velocity.

questions.question_text: Arrange these scenarios in order of work done (least to most) for the same force:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is from least to most work done: force perpendicular to displacement (cos 90 = 0), force at 60 degrees to displacement (cos 60 = 0.5), force at 45 degrees to displacement (cos 45 = 0.707), and force in the direction of displacement (cos 0 = 1). This is because the cosine term in the work formula determines how much of the force contributes to the work done.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: force perpendicular to displacement, force in the direction of displacement, force at 60 degrees to displacement, and force at 45 degrees to displacement. This is incorrect because the cosine term in the work formula plays a crucial role in determining the work done. The force in the direction of displacement (cos 0 = 1) would do the most work, followed by the force at 45 degrees (cos 45 = 0.707), then the force at 60 degrees (cos 60 = 0.5), and finally the force perpendicular to displacement (cos 90 = 0).

questions.question_text: Arrange the positions of a roller coaster from highest to lowest PE:
ordering_items: At the bottom of the track
At the top of the first hill
At the top of the second hill (lower than first)
correct_answer: At the top of the first hill
At the top of the second hill (lower than first)
At the bottom of the track
questions.explanation_correct: The position with the highest potential energy is at the top of the first hill, as it is the highest point on the roller coaster track. The potential energy decreases as the roller coaster moves down the track, with the top of the second hill having less potential energy than the first hill, and the bottom of the track having the lowest potential energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to put 'At the top of the second hill (lower than first)' before 'At the top of the first hill'. This is wrong because the top of the first hill is the highest point on the track, and therefore has the greatest potential energy. The top of the second hill, being lower, has less potential energy than the first hill.

questions.question_text: How does kinetic energy differ from potential energy in terms of dependence on velocity?

options.text: Kinetic energy depends on velocity squared; potential energy does not depend on velocity
Both kinetic energy and potential energy depend on velocity squared
Potential energy depends on velocity; kinetic energy depends on height
Neither kinetic energy nor potential energy depends on velocity

questions.explanation_correct: Kinetic energy (KE = 1/2 mv^2) depends on the square of velocity, while gravitational potential energy (PE = mgh) depends on height and has no velocity term. This is the fundamental distinction: kinetic energy is energy of motion (velocity-dependent), whereas potential energy is energy of position (height-dependent).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is wrong because potential energy (PE = mgh) has no velocity term at all. Option C reverses the dependencies incorrectly. Option D is wrong because kinetic energy explicitly depends on velocity squared as seen in KE = 1/2 mv^2.

questions.question_text: How does the work done by a force at 0 degrees to displacement differ from the work done by the same force at 180 degrees to displacement?

options.text: Both are equal in magnitude and sign
They are equal in magnitude but opposite in sign
Work at 0 degrees is double the work at 180 degrees
Work at 180 degrees is zero while work at 0 degrees is positive

questions.explanation_correct: At 0 degrees, W = Fd cos(0) = +Fd (positive work). At 180 degrees, W = Fd cos(180) = -Fd (negative work). Both have the same magnitude Fd, but opposite signs. The force at 0 degrees does positive work (force aids motion), while the force at 180 degrees does negative work (force opposes motion).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because the signs differ (positive vs negative). Option C is wrong because the magnitudes are equal, not double. Option D is wrong because work at 180 degrees is not zero; it is negative. Zero work occurs only when the angle is 90 degrees.

questions.question_text: How does work differ from power in terms of dependence on time?

options.text: Work depends on time; power does not
Power depends on time taken; work does not depend on time
Neither work nor power depends on time
Both work and power depend equally on time

questions.explanation_correct: Work (W = Fd cos theta) depends only on force, displacement, and the angle between them -- time does not appear in the formula. Power (P = W/t) is the rate of doing work, so it explicitly depends on the time taken. Two machines can do the same work but have different power ratings if they take different amounts of time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the relationship. Option C is wrong because power does depend on time (P = W/t). Option D is wrong because work has no time dependence in its formula W = Fd cos theta.

questions.question_text: How does the effect of doubling mass differ from the effect of doubling velocity on the kinetic energy of a body?

options.text: Doubling mass quadruples KE; doubling velocity doubles KE
Both doubling mass and doubling velocity quadruple the KE
Doubling mass doubles KE; doubling velocity quadruples KE
Doubling mass doubles KE; doubling velocity doubles KE

questions.explanation_correct: From KE = 1/2 mv^2, kinetic energy is directly proportional to mass (first power) but proportional to the square of velocity. So doubling mass (m to 2m) gives KE = 1/2 (2m)v^2 = 2 times the original KE. Doubling velocity (v to 2v) gives KE = 1/2 m(2v)^2 = 4 times the original KE. Velocity has a greater effect because of the squared relationship.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the effects. Option B is wrong because doubling mass only doubles KE, not quadruples it. Option D is wrong because doubling velocity quadruples KE due to the v^2 term, not merely doubles it.

questions.question_text: How does the total mechanical energy at the top of a free-fall differ from the total mechanical energy just before hitting the ground (assuming no air resistance)?

options.text: It is greater at the top because PE is maximum
It is greater at the bottom because KE is maximum
The total mechanical energy is the same at both positions
It depends on the mass of the object

questions.explanation_correct: By the law of conservation of energy, in the absence of air resistance, the total mechanical energy (KE + PE) remains constant throughout the fall. At the top, energy is entirely PE with zero KE. Just before hitting the ground, energy is entirely KE with zero PE. The total is the same at both positions because energy is only transformed, not lost.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A and B are wrong because although PE is maximum at the top and KE is maximum at the bottom, the total mechanical energy (KE + PE) is identical at both points. Option D is wrong because while mass affects the value of total energy, it does not change the fact that total energy is conserved between the two positions.

questions.question_text: A force acts on a body such that the body's speed decreases and the force opposes the displacement. The work done by this force is classified as:

options.text: Cannot be determined without knowing the angle

questions.explanation_correct: When a force opposes the displacement, the angle between force and displacement is 180 degrees, and cos(180) = -1. This makes the work done W = Fd cos(180) = -Fd, which is negative. The decreasing speed confirms that the force is taking energy away from the body, consistent with negative work.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because positive work requires force and displacement in the same direction (angle = 0 degrees). Option C is wrong because zero work occurs only when the force is perpendicular to displacement. Option D is wrong because the problem already states the force opposes displacement, giving an angle of 180 degrees.

questions.question_text: An object is at rest at a height above the ground, has mass, and is in a gravitational field. The energy it possesses is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: An object that is at rest (zero velocity, so no kinetic energy), has mass, and is at a height in a gravitational field possesses gravitational potential energy (PE = mgh). The three conditions -- mass, height above reference, and gravitational field -- are the defining features of gravitational potential energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because kinetic energy requires motion (velocity), and the object is at rest. Option C is wrong because elastic potential energy requires deformation of a spring or elastic material, which is not described. Option D is wrong because heat energy relates to molecular motion, not the position of an object in a gravitational field.

questions.question_text: A machine receives 1000 J of input energy and produces 600 J of useful output. The remaining 400 J is lost as heat and sound. This machine is classified as having an efficiency of:

options.text: 60% because only 600 J out of 1000 J is useful output
160% because output plus waste exceeds useful output

questions.explanation_correct: Efficiency = (Useful output / Total input) x 100% = (600 J / 1000 J) x 100% = 60%. Efficiency measures only the fraction of input energy that is converted to useful work, not the total energy including losses. Even though total energy is conserved (600 J + 400 J = 1000 J), the efficiency is 60%.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because 100% efficiency would require all 1000 J to appear as useful output. Option C confuses wasted energy with efficiency -- the 40% represents waste, not efficiency. Option D gives a physically impossible efficiency exceeding 100%, which would violate energy conservation.

questions.question_text: A net force does work on a body, causing the body to accelerate from rest. The relationship between the net work done and the change in kinetic energy is classified under which theorem?
questions.explanation_correct: The work-energy theorem states that the net work done on a body equals the change in its kinetic energy. The scenario describes a net force doing work to accelerate a body from rest, which is exactly the situation addressed by the work-energy theorem: W_net = delta KE = 1/2 mv^2 - 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is a broader principle about total energy remaining constant in an isolated system, not specifically about net work equalling change in KE. Option B relates force to acceleration (F = ma), not directly to work and kinetic energy change. Option D deals with conservation of total momentum in collisions, which is unrelated to this scenario.

questions.question_text: Riya pushes a 15 kg box across a smooth classroom floor with a force of 40 N at an angle of 60 degrees to the horizontal. The box slides 3 m along the floor. How much work does Riya do on the box?
questions.explanation_correct: Work = F x d x cos(theta) = 40 N x 3 m x cos(60) = 40 x 3 x 0.5 = 60 J. The angle between the force and horizontal displacement is 60 degrees, so only the horizontal component of Riya's push (F cos 60 = 20 N) contributes to horizontal work. The mass of 15 kg is not needed for this calculation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (120 J) ignores the angle and simply multiplies 40 x 3. Option C (103.9 J) likely uses cos(30) instead of cos(60). Option D (40 J) is not a correct application of the work formula. The key is to use W = Fd cos(theta) with theta = 60 degrees.

questions.question_text: Amit rides his bicycle of total mass 80 kg (including his own weight) at 5 m/s on a level road. He then speeds up to 10 m/s. What is the change in his kinetic energy?
questions.explanation_correct: Change in KE = 1/2 m(v2^2) - 1/2 m(v1^2) = 1/2 x 80 x (10^2 - 5^2) = 1/2 x 80 x (100 - 25) = 1/2 x 80 x 75 = 3000 J. The change in KE is not simply based on the change in velocity but on the difference of the squares of the final and initial velocities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (1000 J) uses 1/2 x 80 x (10 - 5)^2 = 1000 J, which incorrectly squares the difference rather than taking the difference of squares. Option C (4000 J) uses only the final KE. Option D (5000 J) may arise from an incorrect calculation. The correct approach is to compute final KE minus initial KE.

questions.question_text: Priya drops a 0.5 kg ball from the second-floor balcony of her school, 10 m above the ground. Ignoring air resistance, what is the speed of the ball when it has fallen 5 m? (g = 10 m/s^2)
questions.explanation_correct: Using conservation of energy: PE lost = KE gained. mgh = 1/2 mv^2, so v = sqrt(2gh) = sqrt(2 x 10 x 5) = sqrt(100) = 10 m/s. After falling 5 m (halfway), the ball has converted half its initial PE into KE. The mass cancels out in the equation, so the 0.5 kg value is extra information.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (5 m/s) likely divides height by time incorrectly. Option C (14.14 m/s) uses the full 10 m fall instead of 5 m. Option D (20 m/s) would be the speed after falling the full 10 m. The question specifically asks for speed after falling 5 m.

questions.question_text: Rohan uses a motor pump to lift 500 kg of water from a 20 m deep well in 50 seconds at a construction site. If the pump has 80% efficiency, what is the power input to the pump? (g = 10 m/s^2)
questions.explanation_correct: Useful work done = mgh = 500 x 10 x 20 = 100,000 J. Useful power output = 100,000 / 50 = 2000 W. Since efficiency = (output / input) x 100%, we get input power = output power / efficiency = 2000 / 0.80 = 2500 W. The pump must consume more power than it delivers because of the 80% efficiency.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (2000 W) is the useful output power, not the input power -- it ignores the efficiency. Option C (1600 W) incorrectly multiplies output by efficiency instead of dividing. Option D (3125 W) likely uses an incorrect calculation. Since the pump is only 80% efficient, the input power must be greater than the output power of 2000 W.

questions.question_text: Meera's car of mass 1200 kg is moving at 15 m/s when she applies the brakes. The braking force brings the car to rest over a distance of 25 m. Using the work-energy theorem, what is the braking force?
questions.explanation_correct: By the work-energy theorem, work done by braking force = change in KE. The car goes from 15 m/s to 0, so change in KE = 0 - 1/2 x 1200 x 15^2 = -135,000 J. Work done = F x d x cos(180) = -F x 25. So -F x 25 = -135,000, giving F = 135,000 / 25 = 5400 N. The braking force is 5400 N opposing the motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B (10800 N) likely doubles the correct answer. Option C (2700 N) likely divides by 50 instead of 25. Option D (7200 N) may arise from an arithmetic error. The correct method is to equate the work done by friction to the loss in kinetic energy using the work-energy theorem.

questions.question_text: A student claims that whenever a force acts on a body, work is always done. Which of the following is an exception that disproves this claim?

options.text: Pushing a trolley along a corridor
Lifting a book from the floor
Pushing hard against a rigid wall without moving it
Pulling a suitcase along the floor

questions.explanation_correct: Pushing against a rigid wall exerts a force but causes zero displacement. Since W = Fd cos(theta) and d = 0, the work done is zero regardless of how much force is applied. This is a common misconception -- students often confuse effort or fatigue with physics work. Work in physics requires both force and displacement in the direction of the force.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B, and D all involve a force causing displacement, so work is done in each case. Only pushing against an immovable wall results in zero displacement and therefore zero work. The misconception arises because we feel tired pushing a wall, but no physics work is performed without displacement.

questions.question_text: A student says that the total mechanical energy of a body is always conserved during motion. In which of the following situations does this claim NOT hold true?

options.text: A ball falling freely in vacuum
A pendulum swinging in the absence of air resistance
A block sliding on a rough surface
A ball thrown vertically upward in vacuum

questions.explanation_correct: When a block slides on a rough surface, friction (a non-conservative force) converts mechanical energy into heat. The total mechanical energy (KE + PE) decreases because some energy is dissipated as thermal energy. Conservation of total mechanical energy only holds when no non-conservative forces (like friction or air resistance) do work on the system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B, and D all describe situations with no friction or air resistance (vacuum or frictionless conditions), so total mechanical energy is conserved in each. Only the rough surface introduces friction, which dissipates mechanical energy as heat, violating the conservation of mechanical energy.

questions.question_text: A student states that a heavier object always has more kinetic energy than a lighter object. Which situation is an exception to this claim?

options.text: A 10 kg ball moving at 2 m/s and a 5 kg ball moving at 2 m/s
A 10 kg ball at rest and a 1 kg ball moving at 10 m/s
A 10 kg ball moving at 5 m/s and a 5 kg ball moving at 3 m/s
A 20 kg ball moving at 4 m/s and a 10 kg ball moving at 4 m/s

questions.explanation_correct: The 10 kg ball at rest has KE = 1/2 x 10 x 0^2 = 0 J, while the 1 kg ball moving at 10 m/s has KE = 1/2 x 1 x 10^2 = 50 J. Despite being 10 times lighter, the moving ball has 50 J of kinetic energy while the heavier ball has zero. This disproves the claim because kinetic energy depends on velocity squared, not just mass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In Option A, the heavier ball (20 J) does have more KE than the lighter ball (10 J). In Option C, the heavier ball (125 J) has more KE than the lighter ball (22.5 J). In Option D, the heavier ball (160 J) has more KE than the lighter ball (80 J). Only Option B shows the lighter object having more kinetic energy.

questions.question_text: Why is the work done by gravity on a satellite moving in a circular orbit classified as zero and not positive?

options.text: Because the gravitational force is too small at that altitude
Because the gravitational force is always perpendicular to the satellite's displacement along the circular path
Because the satellite has no kinetic energy
Because gravity does not act on objects in space

questions.explanation_correct: In a circular orbit, the gravitational force always points towards the centre (radially inward), while the satellite's displacement at any instant is along the tangent to the orbit (perpendicular to the radius). Since the angle between force and displacement is 90 degrees and cos(90) = 0, the work done by gravity is zero. This is why the satellite's speed and KE remain constant in a circular orbit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because gravity is not negligible in orbit -- it is what keeps the satellite in orbit. Option C is wrong because the satellite has substantial kinetic energy due to its orbital speed. Option D is wrong because gravity absolutely acts in space; it provides the centripetal force for the orbit.

questions.question_text: Why is the energy stored in a compressed spring classified as elastic potential energy and not gravitational potential energy?

options.text: Because the spring is not at a height above the ground
Because the energy arises from deformation of the spring's shape, not from its position in a gravitational field
Because the spring has no mass
Because the spring is not moving

questions.explanation_correct: Elastic potential energy arises due to the deformation (compression or stretching) of an elastic object from its natural shape. Gravitational potential energy arises due to an object's position (height) in a gravitational field. A compressed spring stores energy because of the change in its configuration, not because of its height. The source of energy storage determines the classification.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is partly true but not the correct reason -- even a spring at a height would store elastic PE due to compression. Option C is wrong because springs do have mass. Option D is wrong because being stationary is a feature of all potential energies; the distinction is the source of stored energy (deformation vs height).

questions.question_text: Why is efficiency of a real machine always less than 100% and never equal to or greater than 100%?

options.text: Because real machines always produce more output than input
Because some input energy is always lost to friction, heat, and sound, reducing useful output below total input
Because machines cannot convert energy from one form to another
Because the law of conservation of energy does not apply to machines

questions.explanation_correct: In any real machine, friction between moving parts, air resistance, heat generation, and sound production are unavoidable. These non-conservative forces convert some of the input energy into forms that are not useful output. Since useful output is always less than total input, efficiency (= useful output / total input x 100%) is always less than 100%. This is consistent with the law of conservation of energy -- total energy is conserved, but not all of it ends up as useful work.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because output is always less than input in real machines, not more. Option C is wrong because machines do convert energy between forms -- that is exactly what they do. Option D is wrong because the law of conservation of energy applies universally, including to machines.
